abstract.p: Michael Asch letter notes Jody Rosen's July 2 article neglected to mention major role Jews played in development of American popular culture exemplified in work of Woody Guthrie; photos (S)

block.p: Jody Rosen only mentions the participation of Jews in the development of the ''schmaltzy,'' sanitized view of popular culture exemplified in the work of Irving Berlin. This perspective omits the major role Jews also played in the development of the ''gritty'' expression of American popular culture exemplified in the work of Woody Guthrie. In this regard, I wish to point out that, through Folkways Records, my father, Moses Asch, son of the renowned Yiddish-language author Sholem Asch, published Harry Smith's ''Anthology of American Folk Music'' and Guthrie's ''This Land Is Your Land,'' the two works cited by Rosen as seminal to that tradition.
